title: Beyond In-Distribution Success: Scaling Curves of CoT Granularity for Language Model Generalization
author: Ru Wang (The University of Tokyo), Wei Huang (RIKEN Center for Advanced Intelligence Project), Selena Song (The University of Tokyo), Haoyu Zhang (The University of Tokyo), Yusuke Iwasawa (The University of Tokyo), Yutaka Matsuo (The University of Tokyo), Jiaxian Guo (Google Research, Australia), ...
relevance_why: The insights on Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning can be applied to audio and speech tasks, particularly in enhancing generalization methods when adapting models to novel scenarios, which is critical in audio processing tasks.
background: This study investigates how different data collection strategies, specifically Chain-of-Thought reasoning versus traditional question-answer pairs, impact the generalization capabilities of language models under distribution shift conditions.
contribution: This paper introduces a structured analysis framework to evaluate language model training strategies, achieving improved out-of-distribution generalization through fine-grained Chain-of-Thought techniques.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional methods focus on direct question-answer pairs that optimize for task-specific accuracy without addressing generalization under distribution shifts.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves generalization by employing fine-grained CoT training that systematically breaks down tasks into structured reasoning steps, reducing reliance on shortcuts.

key_innovation: The emphasis on using Chain-of-Thought sequences to model complex dependencies while retaining context increases sample efficiency and generalization.
real_world_impact: These findings could enhance the applicability of language models in real-world scenarios, particularly in fields requiring adaptability to new and unforeseen contexts, such as automated diagnostics or strategic decision-making.
limitations: No significant limitations were mentioned; although high-quality CoT data remains challenging to collect.

new_terms.Chain-of-Thought (CoT): **Chain-of-Thought (CoT)** reasoning involves breaking down complex problems into intermediate reasoning steps, helping models to understand the relationships and dependencies between tasks.
